I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  operational  missions  in  2001,  the 
Government of Viet Nam reconfirmed an earlier request for assistance for the preparation of a 
power  transmission  system  project  to  enhance  overall  power  system  efficiency.  A  project 
preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  for  the  Northern  Power  Transmission  Project  is 
included in ADB’s 2002-2004 Country Strategy and Program (CSP) and an ensuing loan project 
is included for 2004. An ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam from 23 September to 
11 October 2002 and reached an understanding with the Government on the objective, scope, 
cost,  financing,  and  implementation  arrangements  and  the  consultants’  outline  terms  of 
reference for the PPTA.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam’s record in reducing poverty in the 1990s was impressive, with a decline by 
over 20 percentage points between 1993 and 1998 that was accompanied by gains in other 
quality of life indicators. Economic growth in the same period averaged 8.8% annually. Thus, 
sustainable  economic  growth  is  one  of  the  key  ingredients  for  the  Government’s  poverty 
reduction  goal.  Regional  level  analysis  within  Viet  Nam  confirms  the  relationship  between 
growth and poverty reduction. In richer regions, notably the Red River delta and the southeast, 
reduction  in  poverty  incidence  has  been  associated  with  high  farm  productivity  and  more 
opportunities to supplement farm income with nonfarm income. Thus, there is a positive linkage 
in these richer regions between farm and nonfarm output, which accelerates the rate of poverty 
reduction.2  
 
3.  The power sector is an essential underlying input for economic growth and job creation. 
As a result of high economic growth and the very low initial power consumption level, the 
percentage demand for power has been growing at an average of 13% annually for the last 
5 years, and the demand growth during the first 8 months of 2002 has been around 18% 
annualized. The rapid demand growth must be matched with investments in sector expansion to 
ensure the security of the power supply for continued economic growth.  
 
4.  Electricity  of  Vietnam  (EVN),  a  state-owned  corporation,  operates  the  generation, 
transmission, and distribution systems in the country and is also responsible for long-term 
power sector planning. According to the Master Plan for Power Development for Viet Nam over 
the period 2001–2010 (5th Master Plan)3 annual investments of about $1.5 billion are required to 
increase electricity supplies sufficiently to support the Government’s growth projection of 6–8% 
annually. The 5th Master Plan also contains a vision for power sector development up to 2020. 
Given the long-term horizon of the 5th Master Plan, load demand projections and corresponding 
investment projects are further divided into 5-year plans. Projects identified for inclusion under 
the PPTA are from the 5-year period 2006–2010 with a view to the timing of the proposed loan 
project.  
 
5.  The northern region of Viet Nam is one of the fastest economic growth areas in the 
country, especially the development triangle of Hanoi, Haiphong, and Quang Ninh provinces. 
Power demand growth in the triangle has reached such levels that EVN expects shortages in

the northern region by 2005. The doubling of the 500 kilovolt (kV) north-south transmission line 
is thus of highest priority to secure sufficient wheeling of power from south to north; it will be 
completed by the end of 2005.4 Extension of the 500 kV network in the north-eastern part of the 
country is a priority investment for the 5-year plan (2006-2010). The 500 kV line will be required 
to secure evacuation of power from the planned generation expansion for the Hanoi-Haiphong-
Quang Ninh development triangle that is projected to add 2,000 megawatts of capacity by 2010. 
Expansion of 220 kV substations in the development triangle is critical to support the expected 
load  growth  at  the  local  level,  to  ensure  system  reliability  and  stability,  and  to  reduce 
transmission losses. Overloading of lines creates stability problems and may result in loss of 
line that can cause substantial power outages and impact negatively on economic growth.  
 
6.  The National Load Dispatch Center (NLDC), in conjunction with the three regional load 
dispatch  centers  (RLDCs),  carries  out  system  control.  NLDC  controls  the  operation  of  all 
national power plants, 500 kV substations, and 500 kV transmission lines. In addition, NLDC 
maintains  control  over  system  frequency  and  voltage.  RLDCs  control  the  operation  of 
transmission lines and substations from 220 kV to 66 kV, and small power plants. Although EVN 
has the necessary technical systems installed in its substations, major power plants, and control 
centers, they are used only for data acquisition. Supervisory control is not executed, as the 
communication  links  are  not  adequately  secure,  and  many  of  EVN’s  substations  are  not 
equipped with remote terminal units. The substations and major power plants of EVN are 
therefore still manned. To overcome this situation, EVN is considering the purchase of remote 
terminal units and communication equipment for many of the existing substations so that they 
can be brought under the control and supervision of NLDC and the RLDCs. EVN also plans to 
prepare a Master Plan on Development of Load Dispatching Facilities with a view to expected 
subregional (international) power trading by 2010 and continued system expansion.  
  
7.  Rapid  growth  of  the  power  sector  has  required  the  Government  to  consider  the 
introduction of market-based reforms in the way it manages and operates the sector. In 1997, 
the Government issued a Power Sector Policy Statement for a market-oriented power sector 
with greater efficiency and transparency, and lower cost of electricity. Areas addressed in the 
policy statement relate to (i) structural reform and commercialization of sector enterprises, 
(ii) legal and regulatory reform, (iii) electricity pricing, (iv) rural electrification, and (v) electricity 
conservation.  ADB  has  been  supporting  the  Government  in  its  reform  effort  through  the 
provision of several TAs; however, the pace of reform implementation has been slow. In 2001, 
the Government decided to introduce a limited power pool by 2005. Major reform decisions 
taken by the Government include those to (i) introduce competition in the generation and 
distribution  sector,  (ii)  maintain  the  transmission  sector  as  a  government  monopoly,  and 
(iii) introduce  cost-based  bulk  tariffs.  Implementation  of  cost-based  bulk  tariffs  and  further 
development of an efficient pricing mechanism and contractual relationships among EVN’s 
generation, transmission, and distribution businesses to fully recover the cost of service by 2005 
will be crucial for improved performance of the sector and successful introduction of a limited 
power  pool.  To  support  the  Government’s  implementation  of  its  sector  reform  goals,  ADB 
recently approved a TA for Roadmap for Power Sector Reform5 that will define a time-bound 
action plan for restructuring of the power sector. The consultants recruited under the TA will 
provide the necessary support to the Government to meet is reform objectives. On this basis, 
ADB’s lending will continue to support efficient and viable investments in the power sector

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The purpose of the PPTA is to support the Government’s strategy for continued poverty 
reduction  through  sustained  economic  growth  by  assisting  in  the  preparation  of  a  power 
transmission project to ensure a sufficient and stable power supply for the Hanoi-Haiphong-
Quang Ninh development triangle, which has been identified as one of the key economic zones 
of Viet Nam. The project will also improve system stability and security, reduce losses, and 
improve the reliability of supply through (i) the construction of 110 kilometers (km) of 500 kV 
double-circuit transmission line from Quang Ninh to Thuong Tin, (ii) construction of one 500 kV 
substation at Quang Ninh and one 220 kV substation at Van Tri, (iii) extension of one 500 kV 
and  six  220  kV  substations,  (iv) upgrading  of  the  existing  load  dispatch  centers,  and 
(v) preparation of a master plan on development of load dispatching facilities. The PPTA will 
also support the CSP’s focus on investment and support for private participation in power 
through public provision of transmission and distribution.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Key activities to be undertaken under the PPTA cover four major areas: (i) compliance 
with  ADB’s  safeguard  policies;  (ii)  economic  and  financial  evaluations;  (iii)  linkage  among 
economic growth, poverty, and the power sector; and (iv) technical project design. The four 
major areas will include the following scope. 
  
10.  To ensure compliance with ADB’s safeguard polices for the environment and involuntary 
resettlement, detailed field surveys along the planned alignment of the transmission line, the 
sites of the two new substations, and the necessary access roads will be undertaken to identify 
any environmental impacts and to prepare a full inventory of all land and project-affected 
households. Necessary mitigation measures, most suitable implementation arrangements, and 
costing of the mitigation measures will also be prepared. An initial environmental examination 
and a summary initial environmental examination will be prepared. A full resettlement plan will 
also be prepared, since the temporary and permanent loss of productive means for affected 
persons could be significant. The resettlement plan will include design of public information, 
disclosure and grievance procedures, and costing of compensation. The nature of the project’s 
impacts are not expected to cause any specific cultural or social impact on any socioeconomic 
group,  including  indigenous  people,  or  exclude  any  from  benefiting  from  the  proposed 
investment project. Therefore, no specific indigenous peoples plan is required. The summary 
initial social and poverty analysis is provided as Appendix 1. 
 
11.  In addition to financial analysis of the project, the financial management capabilities and 
the financial performance of the executing and implementing agencies will be assessed. EVN’s 
intercompany transfer pricing and bulk tariff structure will be reviewed to determine whether the 
true cost of supply is being adequately recovered and/or being subsidized through a transparent 
mechanism. In addition to economic analysis of the project, economic subsidies involved in the 
current tariff structure and the extent of cross-subsidization between major consumer groups 
and regions will be analyzed. Existing estimates for costs of unserved energy due to unreliability

4 
of the system will be updated; and several scenarios for the load growth forecast, paying 
particular importance to potential impacts of external shocks on the economy, will be developed.  
 
12.  To  analyze  the  way  in  which  the  proposed  investment  project  is  linked  to  poverty 
reduction, a detailed poverty analysis will be undertaken making use of existing surveys and 
provincial data combined with field consultations. The assessment will be carried out at three 
levels: (i) direct, (ii) indirect, and (iii) macroeconomic effects. Particular attention will be paid to 
sector shifts in production activities and unskilled labor intensity of employment opportunities. 
Indicators for benefit monitoring will also be prepared. 
 
13.  For finalization of the technical project design, detailed review of load forecasts will be 
undertaken with a view to ensuring least-cost technical design and economic viability of the 
proposed investment project. Feasibility studies will be reviewed, and a procurement plan will be 
prepared. 
 
14.  The rationale for the proposed 500 kV transmission line and the new 500 kV substation 
is closely related to specific generation expansion projects. Thus, any delay in the construction 
of those plants, or a change in the location of the plants, would make the proposed investments 
in the transmission line and substation unjustifiable. This is a potential risk for project economic 
and financial viability. Since the 5th Master Plan sets out the power sector investment needs 
over a specified period of time and by area (north, central, and south), a sector project approach 
for the ensuing loan would introduce sufficient flexibility in the event that those generation plants 
are  delayed.  Under  the  PPTA,  suitable  selection  criteria  for  specific  area  coverage  and 
components will be developed and decided upon collectively among the Government, EVN, and 
ADB. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated at $875,000 equivalent, of which the foreign 
exchange cost is $556,500 and the local currency cost is $318,500 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $700,000 equivalent, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost 
and a portion of the local currency cost amounting to $143,500 equivalent. The PPTA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the 
remaining  $175,000  equivalent  of  local  currency  costs  through  in-kind  contributions  of  the 
executing and implementing agencies, and partly from Power Engineering Consulting Company 
No.1 (PECC1), NLDC and the Institute of Energy. These will include office accommodation and 
facilities, local communication, counterpart staff, data, and other information needed for the 
PPTA. Detailed cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. The Government has been advised 
that ADB’s approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  EVN, as the Executing Agency for the PPTA, has nominated the Northern Viet Nam 
Power Projects Management Board (NPPMB) to be the Implementing Agency. NPPMB has 
adequate experience with implementing externally funded projects of similar nature. PECC1 and 
the Institute of Energy are carrying out the feasibility studies for the transmission lines and 
substations. The Institute of Energy is also responsible for system planning and for preparation 
of load forecasts. The PPTA consultants will have to work closely with PECC1 and the Institute 
of  Energy,  and  will  have  full  access  to  all  documents  and  data  required  for  PPTA 
implementation. EVN will make sufficient counterpart funds available to PECC1 and the Institute 
of Energy, including for transport and counterpart staff for field visits. EVN will also provide all

5 
necessary assistance to the PPTA consultants in liaising with other Government ministries and 
agencies and with provincial authorities, and in obtaining necessary data and documentation 
from these ministries, agencies, and provincial authorities. EVN will liaise with the provinces 
affected by the proposed investment project to ensure nomination of counterpart staff before 
fielding of the PPTA consultants. As load dispatch requirements are distinct and different from 
those  of  the  transmission  component,  the  Mission  considers  it  necessary  that  the  PPTA 
consultants liaise directly with NLDC for the load dispatch component of the project.  
 
17.  The PPTA will require about 17 person-months of international and 5.5 person-months 
of domestic consulting services. It will be implemented over a 9-month period commencing in 
May 2003. Outline terms of reference for the consultant are provided in Appendix 3. At the initial 
stage of TA implementation, a workshop for provincial and district compensation councils will be 
held to discuss the work to be undertaken by the consultants and ADB’s requirements related to 
resettlement. Tripartite workshops (including the Implementing Agency) will be held after the 
submission of the inception, interim, and draft final reports. The consultants will prepare status 
reports for their specific scope of works highlighting any issues that could become critical for the 
timely completion of the PPTA. The consultants will arrange for other workshops and on-the-job 
training for EVN staff and for provincial and district compensation committees as necessary. 
The  international  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  project  and  energy  economics  and 
macroeconomic modeling, financial analysis and financial management, power system and 
transmission system planning, environmental impact assessment, resettlement, and other social 
issues. A consulting firm or consortium of firms will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Recruitment of consultants will be under the quality and 
cost-based  selection  procedures,  and  simplified  technical  proposals  will  be  requested. 
Equipment to be financed under the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
for Procurement. 
   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam for preparing the Northern Power Transmission Project, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. The technical assistance, initially financed as a grant, will be subject to the 
reimbursement arrangements set forth in Technical Assistance Operations6 and Streamlining of 
Technical Assistance Operations.7 If the technical assistance results in an ADB loan, ADB may 
charge  against  the  loan,  and  recover  from  it,  the  portion  of  the  initial  grant  that  exceeds 
$250,000 equivalent.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
Despite the fact that electrification and electricity consumption are not really to be considered as outcomes, 
the power sector is regarded as fundamental for poverty reduction and economic growth as an input.  Electrification is 
regarded as so important for achieving other development goals that it constitutes a national goal. Consequently, Viet 
Nam has achieved remarkable achievements in expanding electrification, with less than 40% of the households 
connected in the mid-1990s to nearly 80% in 2001. Less than 14% of communes, mainly located in very remote 
areas, are without access to the grid. However, electricity consumption patterns are skewed in favor of urban 
consumers, who represent about 20% of the population but account for over 86% of total consumption. Consumption 
patterns are also skewed in terms of nonpoor and poor consumers, as electricity consumption by the poor tends to be 
determined by affordability of appliances. Despite these patterns, the high connection ratios across most provinces 
suggest that capital investments in the power sector to meet future demand of existing and new consumers can be 
regarded as inclusive of the poor, both directly as consumers and indirectly through the contribution to enabling off-
farm employment opportunities in the private sector and to economic growth.  
 
Poor quality and unreliable supply of power tend to disproportionally burden the poor because they are less 
able to resort to alternative sources of power and because they are less diversified in income sources such that loss 
of one income source may have larger impacts for poor than for nonpoor households. On the other hand, reliable 
supply of power tends to act as an important factor for attracting commercial and industrial activities, which in turn 
may enable the poor to diversify income sources through the increased availability of employment opportunities. The 
ability of provincial governments to fulfill economic development plans to support social development and off-farm job 
creation depends on the availability of sufficient power to support expansion of commercial and industrial activities.      
 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Poverty Classification:  
Beneficiary nonspecific intervention 
Thematic Classification: Economic growth 
 
The poverty analysis will make use of existing surveys and provincial data combined with consultations in 
the field, and will include an assessment on three levels: (i) direct, (ii) indirect, and (iii) macroeconomic effects. 
Mechanisms through which poverty and vulnerability of the near poor are reduced will be identified and subjected to 
qualitative and quantitative assessment. The type and extent of effects, and the mechanisms through which they take 
place, together with key assumptions and risks, will be summarized in matrix form to give an overview of the 
distributional impacts across key socioeconomic groups. The approach may include input-output table analysis1 to 
attempt to assess the impacts on poverty under “with” and “without” project scenarios. To the extent possible, the 
study will include gender as a specific socioeconomic group across poverty status.  
 
Direct Effects on Poverty 
 
While the proposed Project will include specific target provinces, improved power supply is fungible, and

include direct effects, by examining and combining consumer base data and poverty data for specific target provinces 
to  establish  a  poverty  profile  of  consumers,  as  primary  beneficiaries,  and  their  consumption  patterns.  This 
assessment will make use of provincial data and review the results from the ongoing rural electrification impact 
survey2 and the findings of the recently finalized Private Enterprise Survey.3  
 
Indirect Effects on Poverty 
 
The study will include a review of the impact of development aspects, interlinking the projected effects of 
increased power supply with sector growth patterns and employment, on poverty in the target provinces. It will make 
use of provincial data, including labor force surveys and living standard surveys, and development plans of target 
provinces, and will assess the impacts of planned development on labor absorption of unskilled versus skilled labor 
and implications for income and income source diversification for households across socioeconomic groups. It will 
particularly  pay  attention  to  sector  shifts  in  production  activities,  the  ability  of  the  poor  to  benefit  from  job 
opportunities, the unskilled labor intensity of job opportunities, and the sustainability of poverty reduction effects. If the 
data allow, the study will discern for gender effects of employment opportunities. It will include an assessment of 
provincial fiscal implications of development plans (including increased revenue from new establishments) and its 
potential for improved social expenditure allocations and indicators.  
 
Macroeconomic Effects on Poverty 
 
The macroeconomic effects will focus on the type of economic growth that the proposed project will support 
through the provincial and national development plans, and its effects on poverty reduction. It will include an analysis 
of the constraints that specific groups of the poor and vulnerable may face in benefiting from economic growth. The 
analysis will be based on geographical growth patterns across sectors and other relevant key macroeconomic 
variables over time combined with poverty and social indicators derived from the Viet Nam Living Standard Surveys 
(VLSS).4 While linkages between economic growth and poverty reduction are strong in Viet Nam, the sustainability 
and continuation of such impacts and the elasticities of poverty reduction with respect to economic growth may vary 
depending on sector growth patterns. Thus, the expected macroeconomic impacts, will focus on the causality 
between power demand and economic growth, sector growth patterns, and the effects on poverty reduction.     
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis:  
 
A stakeholder analysis will be an integral part of the economic (distributional assessment), poverty and 
resettlement assessments. The stakeholder analysis under the economic and poverty assessments will be mainly 
descriptive to assess the distribution of expected costs and benefits. For transmission line routings, information and 
consultations with people and local communities in affected areas will need to be undertaken. The project preparatory 
technical assistance will design a full participation strategy to be undertaken before and under the construction 
period. The strategy will include design of public information disclosure, compensation and resettlement issues, and 
grievance procedures.  
 
Participation strategy required: Yes – for resettlement and compensation measures.

following:

Investment  Projects  Financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (2001),  the  consultant  will 
conduct financial analysis of the proposed Project and financial performance of the Executing 
Agency, Electricity of Vietnam (EVN), and Implementing Agency, Northern Viet Nam Power 
Projects Management Board (NPPMB). This will include preparation of relevant sections of the 
report and recommendation of the President (RRP) of ADB as outlined below. The consultant 
will 
 
(i)  carry out in-depth financial analysis of the proposed investment (and any defined 
subprojects),  including  calculation  of  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  and 
weighted average cost of capital, taking into account all the financial costs and 
benefits of the proposed Project; 
 
(ii)  identify all risks to project revenue and costs and conduct relevant sensitivity 
analyses on the financial results; 
 
(iii)  prepare a financing plan for the Project, including proposed ADB lending, any 
prospective cofinancing, and appropriate counterpart funds for local currency 
expenditures; 
 
(iv)  review EVN’s intercompany transfer pricing and bulk tariff structure to determine 
whether the true cost of supply is being adequately recovered and/or being 
subsidized through a transparent mechanism; and identify the specific sources 
and projection of revenue from the Project’s subprojects, which will ensure the 
financial viability of the Project, also taking into account the reduction of technical 
line losses and any improvements in operational efficiency; 
 
(v)  review the most current audited and/or unaudited financial statements of EVN to 
assess  (a)  historical  financial  performance,  (b)  retail  tariff  levels,  (c)  capital 
structure, and (d) sufficient generation of internal funds to ensure sustainability of 
ongoing  operations  (i.e.,  self-finance  a  reasonable  percentage  of  capital 
expenditures and service existing debt); the consultant will also review recent 
audited project accounts of NPPMB to determine proper accounting and cost 
control; 
 
(vi)  prepare an appendix to the RRP briefly summarizing past historical and projected 
financial performance, which will include 10-year pro forma financial statements 
(balance sheet, income statement, statement of cash flows) for EVN;

B.  Environmental Aspects (3 person-months, international; 2 person-months, domestic) 
 
3.  In accordance with the relevant guidelines and policies for environmental assessment, 
the consultants will undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant sections of 
the RRP as outlined below. The consultants will 
 
(i)  conduct  an  initial  environmental  examination  for  the  transmission  line  and 
substations, taking into account the likely impacts associated with their locations, 
designs, and construction activities, as well as the long-term impacts during 
operation, including identification of environmental issues from activities directly 
induced by the Project; and paying attention to the wetland near the Quang Ninh 
substation site and the Van Tri substation and its access road; 
 
(ii)  recommend  appropriate  environmental  mitigation  measures  for  identified 
significant impacts and monitoring plans to address these impacts; and assess 
the  environmental  benefits  of  the  proposed  activities  and  any  capacity-
strengthening  measures  that  may  be  needed  for  the  implementation  of 
environmental management and monitoring plans; and 
 
(iii)  prepare an initial environmental examination  report and its summary based on 
the environmental assessment requirements of ADB’s Environmental Guidelines 
for Selected Infrastructure Projects, and any applicable procedures or guidelines 
for environmental assessment as required by the Government; and ensure that 
the costs for implementation of recommended environmental management and 
monitoring plans, and any capacity strengthening measures, are included in the 
proposed Project’s development costs. 
 
C.  Economic Evaluation (3 person-months, international; 1.5 person-months, domestic) 
 
4.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects, the consultant 
will undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant sections of the RRP. The 
consultant will  
 
(i)  conduct an economic and distributional evaluation of the Project by comparing 
with-and  without-project  cases  for  different  load  growth  scenarios;  this  will 
include calculation of the economic internal rate of return (EIRR), taking into 
account economic costs and benefits;

12  Appendix 3 
(ii)  analyze the economic subsidies involved in the current tariff structure and the 
extent of cross-subsidization between major consumer groups and regions; and 
review the appropriateness of the existing lifeline tariff block; 
 
(iii)  update existing estimates of costs of unserved energy due to unreliability of the 
system;  and  develop  several  scenarios  for  the  load  growth  forecast,  paying 
particular attention to the potential impacts of external shocks on the economy; 
 
(iv)  identify risks and undertake appropriate risk and sensitivity analyses with respect 
to EIRR in accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the 
Economic Analysis of Projects; 
 
(v)  identify stakeholders and conduct a distributional analysis of net project benefits 
in accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact in Economic 
Analysis  for  Projects;  calculate  the  poverty  impact  ratio  (PIR)  and  the  cost 
effectiveness of the Project in reducing poverty; and undertake appropriate risk 
and sensitivity analysis with respect to the PIR; 
 
(vi)  specify indicators to monitor the project benefits; and establish procedures and 
provide cost estimates for benefit monitoring and evaluation in terms of ADB’s 
Guidelines for Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation; and 
 
(vii)  prepare a project framework, according to ADB standards, that clearly identifies 
the goals and objectives of the proposed Project, required inputs, targets or 
benchmarks, monitoring mechanisms, potential risks, and assumptions. 
 
D.  Poverty Analysis (2 person-months, international)  
 
5.  The consultant will analyze the development impact of the ensuing proposed Project and 
its potential impact on poverty reduction in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and 
Social Analysis and Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact in Economic Analysis of Projects. 
The consultant will 
 
(i)  based on a review of existing studies, data, and development plans, prepare a 
socioeconomic and poverty profile of primary project beneficiaries in the target 
provinces; include gender and local ethnic minority’s profile and their poverty 
status, and an analysis of deprivation and the causes of poverty and vulnerability 
in the area; 
 
(ii)  analyze access to electricity, affordability, consumption levels, and consumer 
satisfaction  across  socioeconomic  groups  in  target  provinces;  assess  the 
determinants and elasticities of demand for power by socioeconomic groups; and 
conduct demand projections under different growth scenarios. 
 
(iii)  analyze  provincial  development  plans,  the  interlinkage  with  increased  power 
demand, and implications for sector change and employment generation for the 
poor; 
 
(iv)  analyze sector growth impacts of the proposed Project on the country level and 
its  impacts  on  the  poor;  and  review  bottlenecks  for  poverty  reduction  and

(v)  based on input-output tables, assess the direct, indirect, and macro distributional

E.  Engineering Aspects (3 person-months, international) 
 
6.  The consultant will undertake the following tasks including the preparation of relevant 
sections of the RRP. The consultant will  
 
(i)  review the latest revision of the “Master Plan on Power Development of Viet Nam 
in Period 2001–2010 with the Vision to 2020” and assess the load growth, taking 
into consideration the methodology employed in its calculation; 
 
(ii)  confirm that the proposed construction/augmentation of the two 500 kilovolt (kV) 
substations at Nho Quan and Quang Ninh plus the six 220 kV substations at Van 
Tri, Dong Hoa, Trang Bach, Nghi Son, Thai Binh, and Nam Dinh represent the 
least-cost solution for expansion of the system to meet the expected load growth 
in northern Viet Nam; 
 
(iii)  confirm that the Quang Ninh – Thuong Tin 500 kV line is the least-cost solution 
for transmitting power from the expected new generation centers of Cam Pha, 
Uong Bi, and Quang Ninh to nearby load centers and beyond; 
 
(iv)  outline project implementation and procurement arrangements including contract 
packaging and a project implementation schedule; 
 
(v)  prepare  detailed  lists  of  materials,  equipment,  and  works  necessary  for  the 
complete scope of the Project; and estimate their costs separated into foreign 
and local cost components; 
 
(vi)  prepare terms of reference for a master plan to provide direction to EVN in 
upgrading and developing its load dispatching facilities to meet its plans for the 
next 5–10 years; and 
 
(vii)  prepare  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  required  for  project 
implementation.  
 
F.  Resettlement Aspects (3 person-months, international; 2 person-months, domestic) 
7.  In  accordance  with  all  relevant  policies,  handbooks,  and  guidelines  of  ADB  and  in 
particular with ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Handbook on Resettlement, the 
consultant will do the following, including preparation of relevant sections of the RRP. The 
consultant will 
   
(i)  identify and prepare socioeconomic profiles of the Project-affected communities 
in the project areas in terms of household sizes, demographic trends, income 
sources  and  levels,  occupations,  socioeconomic  conditions,  social  service 
infrastructure,  and  social  organizations,  in  accordance  with  relevant  ADB

guidelines  and  publications  and  the  requirements  of  Viet  Nam;  include  the 
gender and local ethnic minority profiles; and carry out any further surveys as 
necessary; 
 
(ii)  undertake a full census and inventory of lost assets (in terms of loss of homes, 
agricultural  and  other  lands;  or  loss  of  access  to  current  income-generating 
activities, including impacts caused by permanent or temporary acquisition) of 
affected people and a baseline socioeconomic survey of the affected population;

(iii)  prepare an entitlements matrix listing all likely effects, both of permanent and of

(iv)  prepare a grievance mechanism and appeal procedures, and mechanisms for

(v)  since the Project is likely to involve significant1 resettlement, an RP should be 
prepared with full stakeholder participation including participation of the executing 
and implementing agencies to be implementable in the Vietnamese context and 
still meet ADB policy requirements.  
     
G.  Reporting and Workshop Requirements 
 
8.  The consultants will prepare inception, interim, draft final, and final reports. Workshops 
among  EVN/NPPMB,  ADB,  and  the  consultants  will  be  held  after  the  submission  of  the 
inception, interim, and draft final reports. Other stakeholders will be invited to attend as needed. 
The consultants will also prepare status reports for their specific scopes of work highlighting any 
issues that could become critical for the timely completion of the TA and that require attention 
from  EVN/NPPMB  and/or  ADB.  At  the  initial  stage  of  TA  implementation  a  workshop  for 
provincial and district compensation councils will be held to discuss the work to be undertaken 
by the consultants and ADB requirements related to resettlement. The consultants will arrange 
for  other  workshops  and  on-the-job  training  for  EVN  staff  and  provincial  and  district 
compensation committees as necessary.
